newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks dragged sharply down by Wall Street.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks dragged sharply down by Wall Street.

text.p: Mexican stocks closed sharply down on Friday after succumbing to a domino effect that spread from Wall Street throughout Latin American markets in the wake of strong U.S. sales and producer prices data, traders said.
"The bourse definitely slid due to developments on the Dow Jones. They propped it up at support but pressure from the U.S. long bond still weighed it down," said Roberto Galvan,
The leading IPC share index ended down 57.29 points, or 1.50 percent, at 3,764.46. Trading volume was moderate at 62.6 million shares.
"U.S. producer price data released early today, and hourly wages last week have fueled exoectations of a rates hike at the U.S. Federal Open Market Committee meeting on May 20," Galvan said.
The Dow Jones plunged 148.36 points to 6,391.69, while the U.S. 30-year Treasury bond was off 21/32 to yield 7.17 percent.
In Brazil, the Bovespa index fell 2.21 percent to 9,518 points, while the Argentine Merval index plummeted 2.79 percent.
Dealers noted a lack of foreign investors in the market.
"Locals are still making the market. Share prices fell on thin volume because most dealers are just switching paper without greatly modifying positions," a floor trader said.

Traders said Telmex L shares weighed down the bourse most and accounted for 21 percent of all shares traded. The telecomms firm's L class ended down 36 centavos at 15.84 pesos, while its ADRs ended off 7/8 at 40.
Financial Group GFB B class was another heavily traded decliner, off six centavos at 2.58 pesos on fears of interest rate hikes that would increase the group's past-due loans burden, traders said.
On the broad market, 102 stocks changed hands, of which decliners outnumbered gainers by 54 to 18.

Cement maker Grupo Cementos de Chihuahua was a prominent gainer list, up 32 centavos to 7.82 pesos on expectations the U.S. Department of Commerce would lower anti-dumping tariffs levied on imports of Mexican cement. Situr, tourist arm of the debt-burdened Sidek group, headed the sliders' list, off three centavos to 20 centavos. Sidek also fell sharply, by three centavos to 31 centavos.
Dealers also drew attention to retail stock Salinas y Rocha which reversed an early gain to close unchanged at 80 centavos, following a denial from the company that it was negotiating an assets sale.
